Marc Gravitt

 
  • Republican Party

Marc Gravitt is running for Tennessee House, 30th District
Back to races

Bio

Marc Gravitt's personal commitment to the safety and prosperity of the 30th District is unquestionable. As a successful small business owner for nearly 25 years, Marc has a practical, efficient, and honest approach to government — one that guarantees he is a representative you can depend upon and trust. His common sense, his commitment, and his proven service make him the strong, effective, conservative voice that District 30 needs in the state Capitol.

Business

Marc's career in public service began after graduating high school and joining the US Army in 1984. He proudly and honorably served our country at home and abroad for six years. Upon leaving the Army, Marc decided to follow in the footsteps of his family, starting his own auction and appraisal business.

Using the values and principles he learned growing up in a family of entrepreneurs, Marc has built Gravitt Auctions & Appraisals, LLC into a thriving business, conducting real estate and business liquidation auctions across the southeast for nearly 25 years. In 2013, Marc was elected President of the Tennessee Auctioneers Association after being an active member for over 20 years.

As a small business owner, Marc understands how to manage complex budgets and negotiate contracts with banks, attorneys, Fortune 500 companies, and various levels of government to get the most for less. This experience has given him the skills and insight needed to create common sense, conservative solutions to the issues facing our state and community.

Leadership

Marc currently serves on the East Ridge City Council where his character and his service have been put to the test. Marc has proven he can listen to both sides of an issue, and he will always consider both the short-term and long-term effects before making a final decision. Marc has built a track record of consistently asking the tough questions and choosing solutions that are fair and to the point.

Marc attends the Christ United Methodist Church where he has served in various leadership positions, including the church council for three years. It was here that he was blessed to meet and marry his wife, Cleo. Marc and Cleo, a teacher at Notre Dame High School, now live in East Ridge. Marc has a son, Jason, who lives in Knoxville and a daughter, Kensley, who is attending the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga.

Capitol

As State Representative for District 30, Marc promises to represent the residents of this community the right way — with sense, dependability, and virtue. If you want someone to watch your tax dollars and have your best interest at heart, vote for an honest businessman. Vote for Marc Gravitt.

Issues

Would you support or oppose an expansion of TennCare under the Affordable Care Act?

Tennessee must balance its budget. If TennCare is expanded, other areas of spending, such as education, will suffer. I will work with our Governor to address the feasibility of a Tennessee Plan that is a defined contribution rather than a defined beneift.

Do you support or oppose more restrictions on abortion in Tennessee?

Tennesseans have the opportunity to vote, as do I, to return the issue of abortion to the General Assembly rather than an unelected body, the judiciary.

What changes, if any, would you support for the state's Common Core education standards?

There must be educational standards that show consistent results that benefit our children. Decisions should ideally be made by our local school board, teachers and parents. Standards should exist to make sure our children receive a quality education that competes in a workforce for high-paying jobs. Concerns about Common Core seem to point to the excessive testing and some of the curriculum. There is a lot of room for improvement.

Should the Hall income tax be reduced, repealed or kept in place?

The Hall Income tax penalizes those who save and invest. The elimination of this tax must be gradual and in a manner that phases out the funding to municipalities that will likely be forced to increase property taxes. Collegedale and East Ridge are two communities in District 30 that receive taxes collected by the Hall Tax. I know that these communities do not want to see an increase in their property taxes as an unintended consequence.

About this guide

There are more than 60 candidates in Hamilton County's Nov. 4 election. Over the past few weeks, Nooga.com sent the candidates brief surveys to help voters get a better understanding of the people who want to represent them in federal, state and local governments. Our guide also features easy-to-read breakdowns of the amendments and ballot measures you'll see on election day.
